UK chancellor says Britain is already being affected by the problems in Europe, as German exports tumble 5.8% in August

  • Latest: IMF announces its new global policy agenda
  • Osborne: Eurozone is threatening UK
fields.headline: Christine Lagarde and George Osborne warn on eurozone, as FTSE 100 slides again
fields.body:
5.53pm BST

Closing Summary

That’s all for tonight, after another day dominated by fears over the health of the global economy in general, and Europe in particular.

A quick reminder of the key points:

IMF managing director Christine Lagarde has warned that the eurozone is seriously at risk of sliding into recession unless all countries, and the ECB, do more.

Lagarde also signalled that she’d like to see Greece sign up to some ‘precautionary support’ (perhaps a credit line?) when its current bailout deal ends.

She was speaking as she outlined the IMF’s Global Policy Agenda, and warned that global growth remains brittle- highlights start here.

And here’s the IMF’s priorities:

Lagarde’s comments came on the day in which Germany received its third dose of bad economic news this week. Exports tumbled by 5.8% in August, in the biggest slump since January 2009.

Economists say Germany will be lucky to avoid a recession.

UK chancellor George Osborne added to the concerns swirling in Europe, saying that the eurozone was already hurting Britain’s economy.

And ECB chief Mario Draghi also weighed in, insisting that countries must reform in order to deliver a recovery...

He also gave Germany a nudge, saying that countries with spare capacity to spend more should do so:

Mario Draghi Took A Not-So-Subtle Swipe At Germany Without Actually Mentioning It By Name

And amid the pessimism, the FTSE 100 fell to its lowest level since last October

In other news.....

The Bank of England left interest rates unchanged again

Greece’s unemployment rate has fallen....

...and it has also sunk deeper into deflation.

And a much-loved Greek riot dog has died

Back tomorrow. Cheers, and goodnight. GW

Updated at 5.53pm BST

5.39pm BST

Another gloomy signal tonight -- Brent crude oil has fallen below the $90 mark for the first time since 2012, as global growth fears linger.

5.19pm BST

Interesting discussion on Twitter tonight about Mario Draghi’s claim that Europe won’t enjoy a recovery unless it implements reforms.

Former BoE policymaker Adam Posen, and FT Alan Beattie, are not convinced:

5.01pm BST

FTSE 100 slides to lowest close since October 2013

The FTSE 100 has just closed at its lowest level in a year, as this morning’s early rally petered out.

The index of blue-chip shares fell 50 points to 6431, a fall of 0.8%, adding to recent losses. Fears over the global economy, and the Ebola crisis, weighed on the City.

Shares are also down on Wall Street, as yesterday’s revival unwinds.

Some traders are expressing disappointment that Mario Draghi didn’t hint at larger stimulus measures, in his speech this afternoon

Alistair McCaig of IG says market optimism was squished by this morning’s weak German export figures:

Today’s German trade balance figures have confirmed, rather than confounded, the growing fears that rather than leading its fellow members into a healthier recovery, Germany is being dragged ever closer to recession.

Here’s Nick Fletcher’s latest market report:

Updated at 5.53pm BST

4.43pm BST

Here’s a few more gems from Germany’s finance minister, Wolfgang Schauble, who has been crossing swords with former US Treasury secretary Larry Summers in Washington:

4.39pm BST

Draghi: Without eurozone reform there can be no recovery

Elsewhere in Washington, Mario Draghi is urging politicians to do their bit to help the recovery by implementing reforms and raising the ‘growth potential’ of their econonomies.

The president of the European Central Bank is singing a familiar song, that monetary policy can’t do it all alone.

Here’s Draghi’s key message:

“Put simply, I cannot see any way out of the crisis unless we create more confidence in the future potential of our economies”....

“given demographic trends, raising structural growth will have to take place primarily through productivity”.

Draghi warns that:

“without reform [in the eurozone], there can be no recovery”.

The ECB chief also warned that governments must also meet their commitments to fiscal reform – a warning to France that missing deficit targets would be dangerous.

“So to now call into question not just the letter, but also the spirit of the fiscal governance framework would be self-defeating. If this were to again cast doubt over fiscal sustainability, it would create a risk that borrowing costs, and hence fiscal policies, turn procyclical once more”.

4.23pm BST

Here’s some reaction to Christine Lagarde’s press conference in Washington (coverage starts here).

John Gizzi, chief political columnist at Newsmax, says US politicians are not happy about the idea of losing influence at the IMF.

But this chart shows why reform is needed:

Lagarde’s comments on Greece and the eurozone didn’t get a universally positive response:

4.07pm BST

Christine Lagarde is now on CNBC (that was quick!), warning that Sierra Leone’s economy will be hit hard by Ebola.

3.51pm BST

Finally, Christine Lagarde says she’s looking forward to the IMF’s next meeting in Peru, where the economy had been struggling in recent months.

3.50pm BST

3.47pm BST

Christine Lagarde declines to comment on the merits of using ‘purchasing power’ to measure China’s relative economic strength versus America.

The bottom line, she says, is that China is growing.

3.46pm BST

Lagarde: Serious risk of eurozone recession unless policymakers act

Q: How close is the eurozone to becoming the new Japan, asks Guardian economics editor Larry Elliott?

We alerted, about a year ago, to the risk of persistent low inflation, says Christine Lagarde.

Measures have been taken by the ECB to try and resist and reverse that risk.

More, we hope, will be done.

And we have now alerted the risk of recession in the eurozone.

We are not saying that the eurozone is heading to recession, but that there is a serious risk of that happening if the right things are not done.

The key is for both “surplus and deficit” countries to do what they have to do, she concludes.

Updated at 3.47pm BST

3.45pm BST

3.42pm BST

Q: Could there be dangerous spillovers, and spillbacks, when the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates?

I cannot predict what the Fed will do, replies Christine Lagarde. Janet Yellen is giving very clear guidance...we can all see what she says. And we can also see delivery of what she has messaged.

On spillovers.... the Fed has studied the ‘taper tantrum’ of 2013, to avoid a repeat.

And yes, spillovers can lead to a spill-back of trouble to the country in question.

3.40pm BST

The IMF has tweeted Christine Lagarde’s call on the US to ratify changes to the IMF’s quotas.

3.38pm BST

3.37pm BST

Lagarde: We think Greece still needs 'precautionary support'

Now, a question on Greece for IMF managing director Christine Lagarde.

Q: After four and a half years, the feeling is that we have had enough austerity and enough pain. The PM has said today that a third bailout won’t be needed, and has sent a team to Washington.

So, can Greece make it without the loans of the IMF and the EU?

Christine Lagarde replies that “All countries, including Greece” must decide how they conduct their own finances.

We are very pleased that Greece has improved its financial position, she says.

But we also believe that going forward, and to deliver a satisfactory environment, it would be in a better position if Greece has “precautionary support”, she adds.

So we are talking about “an evolution of the relationship”, but one that will help the country to move on on its own, Lagarde concludes.

3.32pm BST

Q: Are African countries capable of raising debt in the financial markets and using the funds for valuable infrastructure projects?

African countries have been very successful recently in issuing sovereign bonds, Lagarde replies. They are seen as safer bets than before.

And the IMF plans to share its research on infrastructure spending, to ensure that the money is spent responsibly.

Updated at 3.32pm BST

3.30pm BST

Lagarde calls on US Congress to ratify IMF changes

Q: IMF data shows that China will overtake the US as the world’s largest economy (on a purchasing power basis), but it currently only has 4% of the voting rights. Does that heighten the need to ratify changes to the IMF’s governance?

This is very important, Christine Lagarde agrees, fervently.

The US Congress needs to approve legislation to change the make-up of the IMF. This was due in 2012. It is overdue in 2014. I hope it can be ratified under president Obama’s leadership.

3.26pm BST

Christine Lagarde's Q&A begins

Here we go.

First question.... hasn’t the IMF been calling for these structural reforms for a while? And is infrastructure spending now the best way forward?

Lagarde says the IMF strongly supports the idea that infrastructure spending is used to promote growth, at a time when monetary policy is ensuring that credit is available at a very low cost.

It addresses the demand, and the supply side, of the economy.

And on structural reforms, Lagarde agrees that this issue has been on the table for years.

It’s a question of doing it, not just talking about it.

3.23pm BST

Reminder, Christine Lagarde’s press conference is online here.

She’ll take questions shortly - currently she’s running through the points mentioned earlier.....

3.21pm BST

Christine Lagarde is running through the IMF’s announcements over the last couple of days; growth forecasts cut, risks of a ‘new mediocre’, etc....

3.18pm BST

Christine Lagarde is speaking at a press conference in Washington now.

She starts by telling the room that, in an earlier meeting, she has announced that it’s OK for countries fighting Ebola to widen their fiscal deficits.

Lagarde admits that IMF colleagues may not immediately support that policy, but it’s a sign that the IMF can change and adapt, even at the age of 70.

3.16pm BST

The IMF's new policy priorities

Here are the IMF’s new policy recommendations included in Christine Lagarde’s new Global Policy Agenda:

(if it’s hard to read, this tweet could be easier)

It includes more support for economic demand in the euro area (more QE, perhaps?), and for the US to “safeguard financial stability” (when it starts to tighten monetary policy)

3.11pm BST

Lagarde: Geopolitical tensions have intensified

Christine Lagarde also warns that geopolitical tensions could undermine the already brittle recovery.

She cites the conflict in Ukraine, turmoil in the Middle East, and the outbreak of Ebola as factors that could hampering recovery in affected countries, and hurt confidence elsewhere.

While the impact of the conflict in Ukraine has been relatively contained to date, further escalation could generate significant negative spillovers, both regionally and globally. These would include disruptions in commodity prices, higher risk aversion in financial markets, and erosion of business confidence in trading partners.

Meanwhile, developments in the MENA region could trigger a sharp rise in global energy prices. Finally, a significant expansion of the Ebola outbreak to other countries would pose a significant risk to growth in Sub-Saharan Africa.

3.08pm BST

Christine Lagarde: It's a brittle, mediocre recovery

In her new Global Policy Agenda, Christine Lagarde is spelling out that a brittle, mediocre recovery continues.

The envisaged acceleration in economic activity has again failed to materialize.

Despite massive and welcome monetary support in major advanced economies and slowing fiscal consolidation, the recovery remains uneven and sluggish. Growth, and hence policy advice, are increasingly divergent across countries. Inflation is still below target in many advanced economies and is a growing concern in the euro area, while unemployment has stayed high....

There are some country-specific factors, including last winter’s bad weather in the US, and the Ukraine crisis..

But still....

the continued weakness of investment and economic activity—six years after the global crisis—suggests that bolder policies and more decisive execution are needed to generate balanced, sustainably higher, job-rich, and inclusive growth.

Updated at 3.08pm BST

3.01pm BST

Lagarde calls for "Bold and resolutely executed policies" to help global economy

Breaking: Christine Lagarde, head of the International Monetary Fund, is calling on politicians and policymakers to do more to stimulate growth and avoid the global economy hitting trouble again.

Speaking in Washington now, Lagarde is demanding “Bold and resolutely executed policies” to ward off the danger of long-term mediocre growth, with “unacceptably low job creation and inclusion”.

Lagarde wants to see

1) structural reforms to boost growth, help confidence, and create jobs

2) stronger regulation and policy frameworks to prevent the flow of “easy money” destabilising the financial markets

3) More international ‘coherence’ to avoid avoid exacerbating existing distortions, particularly regarding financial stability and global imbalance.

More to follow.....

2.54pm BST

Heads-up. International Monetary Fund managing director Christine Lagarde is due to hold a press briefing in a few minutes to discuss the global agenda for this week’s IMF/World Bank meeting.

It’s being streamed live here.

2.50pm BST

Here’s more gloomy analysis of the slump in German exports in August (down an alarming 5.8% month-on-month), from Richard Grieveson of the Economist Intelligence Unit:

“Coming on the back of the recent plunge in industrial output, this is another disastrous number that tallies with our long-held view that the German economy would suffer badly from euro zone weakness, the exchange of sanctions between the EU and Russia, and slower growth in China. There are reasons to think that the August export and industry numbers are a bit overstated given the strong July readings, but overall the negative trend is painfully clear. We will need a very strong set of data for September—something that the high frequency sentiment indicators suggest we won’t get—for Germany to avoid entering technical recession.

“It’s hard to see how any of the factors driving the weakness in German industry and exports will disappear in the next 2-3 quarters. Things may well get worse before they get better, and the feed-through channels of external weakness to the domestic economy are pretty clear, given the importance of export-orientated industry for German employment and growth overall.

“Germany’s ever-growing importance to aggregate euro zone growth (with the exception of Q2) indicates that things could get very messy in the bloc in the next few quarters. Pressure for monetary and (German) fiscal action to alleviate the downturn will increase, but politically we think the ECB has reached its limit, and higher public spending or investment in Germany will be strongly resisted domestically”

Updated at 4.44pm BST

2.47pm BST

2.33pm BST

2.32pm BST

Update: Wolfgang Schäuble is making those comments about German growth during an event at Bertelsmann Foundation - here’s a livestream.

2.29pm BST

German finance minister: We must fight for more growth

Some quotes from Germany’s finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, are flashing up on the Reuters terminal.

Schäuble, who is in Washington for the IMF/World Bank meetings, is acknowledging that Europe has a growth problem (a problem that is now lapping at Germany’s doorstep).

But he is also insisting that budget rules can’t simply be torn up; a blow to hopes that Germany could give eurozone neighbours more leeway.

Here are the newsflashes:

  • GERMANY’S SCHAEUBLE SAYS SOME RISKS AFFECT GERMANY MORE THAN OTHER EURO ZONE COUNTRIES
  • GERMANY’S SCHAEUBLE SAYS NOW WE HAVE TO FIGHT FOR MORE GROWTH IN EUROPE, WILL HAVE DISCUSSIONS IN COMING DAYS
  • GERMANY’S SCHAEUBLE SAYS EUROPE WILL BE ASKED TO DO MORE ON GROWTH, ALL AGREE
  • SCHAEUBLE: IF WE DON’T STICK TO THE EU BUDGET RULES, MONETARY UNION DOESN’T WORK
  • SCHAEUBLE: GERMANY IS ENGINE OF GROWTH IN EURO ZONE, WE STICK TO 1.5 PCT
  • SCHAEUBLE: WE HAVE TO GIVE MORE PRIORITY TO INVESTMENT

2.16pm BST

From Athens, correspondent Helena Smith writes that the news of riot dog Loukanikos’s death could mark the end of one of Greece’s most turbulent periods -- if the Greek prime minister is to be believed, anyway.

Antonis Samaras, currently in Milan for a conference addressing the every worsening problem of unemployment in Europe, has told reporters during his visit that the debt-stricken country is now on the path to growth.

He also feels ‘absolutely confident and very comfortable” about Greece now exiting its EU-IMF bailout programme.

2.04pm BST

Wall Street is taking Carl Icahn’s “Dear Tim” letter in its stride....

1.57pm BST

Carl Icahn urges Apple to accelerate share buybacks

Activist investor Carl Icahn has called on the board of Apple to speed up its share buyback scheme, before other investors realised that the company is undervalued.

In an open letter to the company, Icahn starts by praising CEO Tim Cook and colleagues:

As a large Apple shareholder with approximately 53 million shares, we applaud you and the rest of management, especially in light of recent launches and announcements which further validate our view that you are the ideal CEO for Apple...

I’m sure Cook is suitably chuffed.

But Icahn goes on! Arguing that Apple is really worth a mighty $203 per share today, not the $100.98 at which it closed last night.

So, Icahn wants Cook to put Apple’s cash pile to work to buy back shares - driving up the value of other stakes (such as his own, naturally):

Therefore, given the persistently excessive liquidity of $133 billion net cash on Apple’s balance sheet, we ask you to present to the rest of the Board our request for the company to make a tender offer, which would meaningfully accelerate and increase the magnitude of share repurchases.

Icahn outlines how Apple has a gloriously bright future, thanks to the iPhone, Apple Pay, even the Apple Watch (there’s a flurry of rather optimistic predictions on future product growth)

And Icahn concludes by sounding a teensy bit impatient, predicting that lesser investors without his nose for opportunity will probably pile into Apple sooner or later...

With more and more funds flowing from mutual funds to index funds (because mutual funds have consistently failed to outperform) the last thing they will want to see is their underperformance exacerbated by remaining underweight Apple as it continues to outperform.

As the strength of the earnings growth we forecast materializes, and these funds scramble to correct this mistake, only to find themselves competing in the market to do so, a de facto short squeeze may occur, and we can only hope that the company has repurchased all the shares it can before that happens.

Business Insider has uploaded the whole letter.

Updated at 2.08pm BST

1.36pm BST

More good US jobs data

Here comes the weekly US unemployment data.....

...and the number of people filing new jobless benefits claims has fallen again, by 1,000 to 287,000.

The four-week average of initial claims also fell, to 287,750, the lowest since February 2006.

The ‘continued claims’ total (people filing jobless claims for at least their second week running), also fell. It hit 2,381m, the lowest since May 2006.

Another sign that America’s labour market is in much better shape than Europe’s. But that, of course, raises the question of when the Federal Reserve will bite the bullet and start raising interest rates.

1.15pm BST

So, is George Osborne right to say that Britain is already being affected by the eurozone?

Well, there certainly are signs that the strong UK recovery seen earlier this year has faded a little.

On Tuesday, for example, the NIESR thinktank predicted that UK GDP rose by 0.7% in the third quarter of 2014, down from 0.9% in April-June (we get the official reading in two weeks).

The monthly PMI surveys showed that growth in the UK private sector slowed to a six-month low in September.

And July’s trade data showed that 95% of Britain’s export growth was to countries outside the EU.

Europe’s economy, meanwhile, has certainly weakened. Its private sector virtually stagnated last month, led by the weak French economy.

Eurozone GDP stagnated in the April-June quarter (when Germany fell into recession), and may have grown by only 0.2 or 0.3% in Q3. That’s too weak to make a dent in Europe’s unemployment crisis, and would also have a knock-on effect on UK firms.

Updated at 1.25pm BST

12.42pm BST

12.37pm BST

Here are some more newsflashes from George Osborne’s warning about the eurozone; the chancellor appears to be chivvying the European Central Bank to do more:

  • UK’S OSBORNE SAYS BRITAIN ALREADY BEING AFFECTED BY WEAKNESS IN EURO ZONE
  • UK’S OSBORNE SAYS UK BETTER PLACED TO WEATHER ECONOMIC STORM DUE TO ACTION TAKEN OVER LAST 4 YEARS -BBC
  • UK’S OSBORNE SAYS NEEDS ECB TO DO ITS PART TO HELP EURO ZONE ECONOMY -BBC

12.32pm BST

Osborne: UK isn't immune to problems in the eurozone

UK chancellor George Osborne has warned that the weakening eurozone economy is already hurting the UK.

Speaking to the BBC, at the start of the IMF’s meeting in Washington, Osborne warned that Britain isn’t “immune” from events in Europe.

Here are the key quotes (via PA):

“This is a critical moment for the British economy. The eurozone risks slipping back into crisis. Britain cannot be immune from that. It’s already having an impact on our manufacturing and our exports,”

Osborne adds that Britain needn’t panic:

“We need to send clear message out around the world that we have a stable economy, that our economic plan is working, and that we are not going to deviate from that economic plan so that people around the world know that, while Britain is not immune from what is going on the world, we can take steps to protect ourselves.”

Osborne’s warning comes amid a blizzard of bad economic news from the eurozone.

Earlier this week, the IMF cut its growth forecasts for Germany, France and Italy, and warned that the eurozone was a key risk to the recovery.

As we’ve been covering this morning, economists are concerned that Germany could be falling into recession. Exports plunging in August at their fastest rate since January 2009 (see opening post), and factory orders and production also suffered alarming declines.

Four of Germany’s most important economic forecasters have also predicted today that the economy stagnated in the last quarter.

The institutes (Ifo of Munich, DIW of Berlin, RWI of Essen and IWH of Halle) warned:

“After gross domestic product contracted in the second quarter and likely stagnated in the third quarter, the economic engine is finding it difficult to get going.”

Updated at 12.44pm BST

12.16pm BST

We have to wait a fortnight to find out how many Bank of England policymakers (if any) wanted to raise interest rates at this week’s meeting.

IHS Global Insight’s Howard Archer reckons the MPC was split 7-2, for the third month running:

We doubt that any more MPC members joined Martin Weale and Ian McCafferty in voting for an interest rate hike at the October meeting.

There has been little indication that any of the other seven MPC members are leaning towards an immediate tightening of policy.

12.04pm BST

12.01pm BST

12.00pm BST

Bank of England leaves interest rates unchanged.

The Bank of England has voted to leave UK interest rates unchanged at 0.5%.

That means borrowing costs have been at their current record low since March 2009.

It has also left its quantitiative easing programme unchanged, at £375bn.

No surprises there.

11.47am BST

Greek riot dog passes away

Sad news from Greece – Loukanikos, the valiant dog who faced down Greek riot police during the height of the eurozone crisis, has died.

Greek media report that Loukanikos (Greek for sausage) passed away peacefully, having retired from protests in 2012.

Curiously, there are also reports that poor Loukanikos may have died a few months ago, but it’s only just come to light....

webTitle: FTSE 100 hits 12 month low on economy and Ebola fears

fields.standfirst: Initial enthusiasm after Fed minutes disappears on German growth worries
fields.body:
On 10 October 2013, the FTSE 100 was sitting at 6430, before subsequently rising - albeit in a rather volatile way - to its recent peak of 6878 in May.

Now a year later the leading index has fallen all the way back, closing down 50.39 points at 6431.85.

It did not look like that at the start of the day, with markets enthused by the US Federal Reserve minutes which suggested fears of an early interest rate rise were misplaced.

But this optimism soon faded, as the current worries about global growth and geopolitical concerns reasserted themselves.

This week has seen a raft of poor data, from Germany in particular, and a 5.8% fall in exports reinforced fears about a possible recession in what is supposed to be the eurozone's powerhouse. Coming in the wake of the IMF cutting its global growth forecasts, that brought the sellers out once more. Comments from Chancellor George Osborne that the eurozone weakness was already hitting the UK economy also dented sentiment.

Added to that, was the continuing concern about air strikes on Isis, the situation in Ukraine and of course the spread of the Ebola virus.

The market falls accelerated as Wall Street opened, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 180 points by the time London closed.

A number of UK companies went ex-dividend including Kingfisher, which fell 15.9p to 296.8p, and Aviva, down 499.3p.

Among the other fallers, Vodafone fell 6.95p to 197.35 as Nomura, highlighting competition worries, cut its target price to 180p from 190p and moved to reduce from neutral. Meanwhile Espirito Santo's Andrew Hogley issued a sell note at the prospect Vodafone might overpay for Italian broadband firm Fastweb, said to have been put up for sale by owner Swisscom.

Worries about the impact of Ebola on travel and tourism saw easyJet lose another 37p to £13.41 while Tui Travel fell 10.1p to 356.9p.

Oil fell back once more, with Brent crude currently down 1.4% at $90.1 a barrel, on oversupply and the prospect of falling demand, given global economic weakness.

However metal prices moved higher as the dollar weakened following the suggestion the Fed would not raise rates prematurely. So Mexican precious metals miner Fresnillo was up 46.5p to 770p and Randgold Resources rose 248p to £42.98. Numis said:

We stick with our defensive criteria; our [mining] picks remain Randgold, Fresnillo and Petra which have superior growth profiles to counter-act flat to falling commodity prices, high quality assets to weather any downturn and strong management to deliver on business plans.

Rio Tinto rose 64p to £30.53 as Credit Suisse suggested Glencore, down 4.9p at 321.75p, could come back for another tilt at the iron ore specialist when it was allowed in six months time. Analyst Liam Fitzpatrick said:

[After] Glencore's announcement that it was not actively considering a merger or offer [it] is now for the next six months subject to Rule 2.8 of the City Code on Takeovers and Mergers (no offer without the consent of the Takeover Panel). However, this far from rules out a bid further down the line, in our view.
There have been a number of unsuccessful deals in recent years (BHP/Rio, Vale/Xstrata, Xstrata/Anglo American) and...there are major obstacles to a deal not least of which is the polar opposite company cultures and buy in from major Rio shareholders (Chinalco, Ltd shareholders). However, big deals typically occur at the peak or trough of the cycle and the synergies on offer together with the potential to re-rate Rio through diversification could become all the more compelling if iron ore continues to move lower in 2015/16. Glencore may therefore be happy to play the waiting game but we expect the prospect of a second approach to remain an overhang.

Back among the losers Associated British Foods - owner of British Sugar as well as the more high profile Primark - fell 12p to £25.53 after Germany's Suedzucker said the European sugar and ethanol markets had continued to deteriorate.

Among the mid-caps, Hays was 2.7p higher at 122.7p after the recruitment group reported an underlying 9% rise in first quarter fees, following strong demand in the UK, Australia and Germany.

Lower down the market New British Palm Oil was in demand after it received a £1.073bn or 715p a share offer from Malaysian plantation owner Sime Darby. Sime Darby director Anthony Dass said:

As a brown field asset, New British Palm Oil will immediately contribute to earnings without the incumbent risks associated with green field expansion.

The move comes just days after Sime Darby said it would not by the 49% stake in New British Palm Oil owned by Malaysian investment firm Kulim.

The company, which has land holdings in Papua New Guinea, said it would recommend the bid, and Kulim said it would accept it, unless a higher offer came in.

New British Palm Oil jumped 286p or 74% to 670p while fellow producer M P Evans also benefited, up 7% to 457.625p. Analyst Charles Hall at Peel Hunt said:

Only 10 days after stating that it had decided not to proceed with an offer for Kulim's shares, Sime Darby has now announced a cash offer at 715p (an 85% premium) for the entire company. Assuming Kulim agrees and given approval from the Papua New Guinea government, this deal should go through. The size of premium reflects the long term prospects for palm oil rather than the current weakness in the palm oil price. It also continues the theme of consolidation in the industry and demonstrates the value in MP Evans.
It appears that the termination of the talks with Kulim (who own 49%) was more due to time constraints rather than desire to proceed. Post the termination, New Britain's management was able to be involved and to help secure the necessary agreements. This deal values New Britain at $28,000 per mature hectare and $25,000 including immature hectares, though this does include the downstream and sugar assets. This looks an attractive price given the current palm price, at which level New Britain is moderately profitable. The price demonstrates the long term value in plantation assets rather than the short term issues. It also demonstrates the value in MP Evans, which is trading on c$10,000 per hectare. We expect consolidation in the industry to continue given the increasing difficulty of finding new land.

webTitle: FTSE on course for lowest close for a year as early exuberance disappears

fields.standfirst: Worries about eurozone economy and Germany outweigh benefits of dovish US Fed
fields.body:
The early gains made by markets in the wake of more dovish than expected minutes from the US Federal Reserve have soon evaporated.

Optimism that a US rate rise was further away than some had feared has been outweighed by continuing concerns about the state of the global economy, notably in the eurozone and, in particular, Germany.

To add to the litany of bad economic news from Germany came a 5.8% slump in exports in August, raising further fears the country could be facing recession.

On top of that, of course, there are the underlying geopolitical worries - Isis, Ukraine, the spread of Ebola.

So the FTSE 100, which hit 6544 in the morning, is now down 45.01 points at 6437.23, on course for its lowest close for a year.

The falls accelerated as Wall Street opened, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average currently 112 points lower after Wednesday's Fed fuelled rise. Jasper Lawler, market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

The post-Fed minutes exuberance didn't last too long in Europe when reality sank in that Europe's still in trouble after more weak data from Germany and the bankruptcy of Espirito Santo Financial Group offered a reminder of the fragility of the European banking system.

webTitle: N Brown shares slump after profits warning

fields.standfirst: Online fashion business, which includes JD Williams, blames ‘unseasonably mild autumn’ for poorer than expected figures
fields.body:
Shares in N Brown dived 13% after the online fashion business warned profits would be hit by the Indian summer despite a marketing push fronted by the TV presenter Lorraine Kelly.

The company, which owns Figleaves, Simply Be and JD Williams, was the biggest faller in the FTSE 350 after it admitted that “unseasonably mild autumn temperatures in September and so far in October” would result in annual pre-tax profits of between £88m and £92m, about £15m less than analysts had expected.

Sales at other fashion retailers – including Next, Debenhams and Marks & Spencer – are also thought to have been affected by September’s warm and dry weather, which have prompted a spate of discounting across the high street. Next warned last month that if the mild weather continued throughout October the retailer would have to lower profit forecasts.

Analysts at M&S’s joint broker Citi also trimmed full-year profits forecast for the retailer by 1.5% to £650m as they predicted underlying sales of clothing and homewares were likely to have fallen by 4% over the summer.

Industry analysts said they were surprised by the warning as just three weeks ago N Brown’s chief executive, Angela Spindler, had said the company was on track, to meet its profits hopes.

“While we believe management’s strategy is right for the businesses long term, arguably management has been too ambitious in its change programme. Anticipated customer response and execution has been poor,” said Kate Calvert, an analyst at Investec.

Jonathan Pritchard, at Oriel Securities, said N Brown’s poor trading could also be down to management trying to do to much too quickly.

“If the poor September sales number was simply to do with the weather, then surely there is pent-up demand, now that the brands are, according to the company, resonating so well with customers?” he said

The disappointing start to the second half of N Brown’s financial year comes despite the launch of a TV advert for JD Williams featuring Kelly as well as changes to the timing of marketing spending and other tweaks – including cutbacks in the amount of less profitable electrical goods being sold and a tightening of credit policy.

Pre-tax profits fell by 3.2% to £42.7m in the six months to 30 August while sales dipped by 0.6%. The figures, released on Wednesday, included a £1.7m loss in the US, where N Brown operates the Figleaves brand, and £0.5m of losses from the set-up of Simply Be stores.

Spindler said: “Despite the negative effects of recent market conditions on performance, I am confident that we are taking the right actions and are making good progress.”

She said the number of active customers increased by 3.7% in the six months to 30 August compared with the same period last year, with 26% more shoppers at JD Williams. Sales were also strong in company’s high-street stores with underlying sales up by 17% during the period. There will be 14 Simply Be/Jacamo stores trading by Christmas.

webTitle: Five charts that show Germany is heading into recession

fields.standfirst: Europe’s largest economy is on the verge of recession following contraction in the second quarter and weak data for the third
fields.body:
Germany is on the brink of recession. Recovery in Europe’s powerhouse went into reverse in the second quarter when the economy shrank by 0.2%.

All the evidence suggests the weakness persisted in the third quarter amid tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine and a flagging recovery in the eurozone economy.

Here are five charts underpinning expectations of a fresh German recession.

Germany’s trade position is deteriorating

German exports fell by 5.8% in August. It was the biggest drop since the early stage of the financial crisis in January 2009. Imports also shrank, by 1.3%. It was worse than the 4% fall in exports and 1% rise in imports forecast by economists.

Given Germany’s reputation as a manufacturing and exporting powerhouse, it does not bode well for Europe’s largest economy. The drop in exports narrowed Germany’s trade surplus to €17.5bn (£13.8bn) from €22.2bn (on a seasonally-adjusted basis).

Carsten Brzeski, economist at ING, described the figures as a “horror story”.

German investors are feeling pessimistic

The ZEW indicator of German economic confidence is followed closely around the world. The measure of investor confidence is considered to be a useful signal of turning points in the economic cycle.

In September, the index fell for a ninth consecutive month to 6.9 points, as investor nerves persisted amid heightened uncertainty about the prospects for the German and eurozone economies in the coming months.

German production has been shockingly poor

Industrial production slumped 4% in August according to Germany’s statistics office. It was an unwelcome surprise for investors and economists, following market predictions of a much smaller 1.5% contraction.

webTitle: Former Caja Madrid directors accused of misusing company credit card

fields.standfirst: Eighty-three executives collectively spent €15m over 10 years at savings bank that merged to become Bankia before 2012 bailout
fields.body:
Fresh evidence is emerging of the spendthrift lifestyle of the directors of the once-mighty Caja Madrid savings bank even as the 300-year-old institution drifted into crisis.

The 83 directors were each issued with a “black” credit card, with the collective bill reaching €15m (£12m) over a 10-year period. The money was spent on holidays and shopping trips, with €3m spent in restaurants.

In the 12 months before its 2012 bailout, Caja Madrid paid out more than €1m in daily allowances and its directors received 1,200 gifts, while chief executive, Miguel Blesa, spent €10,000 on wine out of the total of €436,700 he ran up on the credit card. This was on top of his €3.5m salary. Former finance director Ildefonso Sánchez Barcoj topped the spending list, with €484,200 on his card.

All of the directors were political appointees, installed by their respective parties and trade unions. José Antonio Moral Santín, of the leftwing Izquierda Unida party, used his card to take out €365,000 in cash. Twenty-two directors continued to use their cards after they had ceased to have any role at the bank.

In 2010, Caja Madrid merged with a series of smaller savings banks to become Bankia. On 9 May 2012, the bank reported a profit of €328m, a figure that was adjusted two weeks later to a loss of €4.3bn. One year on this was revised to €19bn, the largest corporate loss in Spanish history.

Bankia was bailed out in 2012 by the Spanish government, which took a 45% stake in it. Earlier this year the government sold 7.5% for €1.3bn.

Blesa and the former Bankia chief executive and economy minister Rodrigo Rato have been summoned to appear before a judge to answer questions about the credit card scandal. Four executive directors have between them repaid a total of €200,000.

webTitle: Greece's riot dog Loukanikos dies

fields.standfirst: Loukanikos, the valiant dog who faced down Greek riot police during the height of the eurozone crisis, has died
fields.body:
Sad news from Greece – Loukanikos, the valiant dog who faced down Greek riot police during the height of the eurozone crisis, has died.

Greek media report that Loukanikos (Greek for sausage) passed away peacefully, having retired from protests in 2012.

Loukanikos began hitting the headlines in 2010, when the stray hound began appearing in the front line of anti-austerity protests.

Athens journalist Damian Mac Con Uladh reports that Loukanikos suffered from his years on the front line.


According to Avgi journalist Petros Katsakos, the dog’s health was adversely affected by tear gas and from being kicked from police, forcing him to “retire” from active protest about two years ago.

“He was on the couch sleeping, when suddenly his heart stopped beating,” Loukanikos’ carer told Avgi.

At the height of his fame, Loukanikos even feature in Time Magazine’s review of 2011 (full details).

Loukanikos ‘retired’ in autumn 2012, around the time that the eurozone crisis was easing. He swapped tear gas and riot shields for a gentler life with an Athens family, who offered“all the care, love, food and vaccinations” a dog could could need.

webTitle: Strategist Albert Edwards warns again market may have peaked

fields.standfirst: Noted stock market bear points to increasing nervousness and volatility
fields.body:
Noted stock market bear Albert Edwards is back and as downbeat as ever.

In a note entitled Basket trade suggests "Sell everything and run for your lives" (a reference to an FT letter explained below), the Societe Generale strategist even admits he sounds like a stopped clock for forever predicting a market crash.

However there is no doubt he is right when he talks about growing nervousness and volatility. Leaving the day's positive market moves aside, the FTSE 100 for one has seen a fall of more than 5% since its recent peak not much more than a month ago (4 September). Edwards says:

All investors have a sure-fire signal for when to liquidate their portfolios and head for the hills. We highlight one investor's concern that markets are a 'basket case'. Certainly you can feel the increasing nervousness in the market. Volatilities are definitely on the rise.
Institutional investors are also getting increasingly nervous that we have reached the end of the road and a major market top may be forming in equities. Notwithstanding particularly concerning economic data out of the formerly reliably robust Chinese and German economies, many market commentators are pointing out that US inflation expectations have now slid to levels that previously triggered the Fed to enact QE - yet there seems to be absolutely no prospect of that occurring currently. Quite the reverse. So maybe it's time to stop dancing and sit this one out. Am I calling a top? What's the point? As an uber-bear I am used to being called a stopped clock. By contrast the market embraces a bullish forecaster however often they are shown to be overly optimistic. The IMF's forecasts for world growth have just been published and guess what - it sees world growth rebounding, just as it has done consistently for the last few years! The market doesn't care that the IMF has been serially wrong and that its forecasts resemble a series of hockey sticks (H/T Zero Hedge). The market loves a bull, even if it is a stopped clock too. I have to commend a letter to the editor in the weekend Financial Times from a Matt Long. He clearly identifies current conditions as entirely consistent with the top of the bubble. This is the sort of incisive analysis that is often so lacking in our industry, Sir:
The next financial apocalypse is imminent. I know this to be true because the (FT Weekend) House and Home section is now assuming the epic proportions last seen before the great crash. Twenty four pages chock full of adverts for mansions and wicker tea trays for $1,000. You're all mad.
Sell everything and run for your lives.
Matt Long, Seilh, France.

webTitle: Appointing women at senior level helps businesses, says Adnams’ first female executive director

fields.standfirst: Karen Hester started out in 1988 as a part-time cleaner at the Suffolk brewer and now runs the company’s day-to-day operations
fields.body:
In 1988, Karen Hester took a job as a part-time cleaner at Adnams to earn money while caring for her two children. Now she runs the entire company’s day-to-day operations and will join the Suffolk brewer’s board as its first female executive director in April.

There was, Hester says, never a game plan as she rose through the ranks at Adnams. She got her cleaning job after returning to Suffolk from Germany where she and her husband were posted in the army.

Hester, 52, joined up from school and drove trucks and ambulances after becoming the youngest woman in Britain to get her heavy goods vehicle licence at the age of 17. When based at Aldershot, one of her jobs was to drive the chaplain to families of servicemen killed in the Falklands to tell them of their loss.

Her break at Adnams came when she got talking to Andy Wood, now Adnams’ chief executive, who joined as head of logistics in 1994. “He asked my background and said: ‘Why don’t you come and work for me and do transport again?’ But you know what women are like. I said it was a long time ago and I didn’t want to do it again.”

A year later, Hester separated from her husband and part-time work was no longer an option so she thought again about Wood’s offer.

“I either had to give up work and go on benefits or work more and I chose to work more.”

She told Wood she would join him if he paid her £2 an hour more. He beat her down to an extra £1 and then said she should not have relented because she was worth the extra £2. But the negotiation got her the job of transport clerk.

In 2000, Hester became Adnams’ head of logistics and in 2007 she was made operations director. By 2011 she had added human resources, sales, hotels, manufacturing to her empire.

“I wouldn’t say I had a grand plan. I’m the sort of person who thinks whatever job you’re doing if you do your best something better will happen.”

Hester is just the sort of woman Vince Cable, the business secretary, wants to see breaking into the boardroom. Adnams already has two women directors but they are non-executives who oversee but do not run the business as Hester does.

The government is pressing companies to promote women after Lord Davies, the former trade minister, set a target of 25% female boardroom representation by next year across FTSE 100 companies. He urged businesses outside the top 100 listed companies such as Adnams to do the same.

With the government approaching its target, Britain is among the top five countries in the world for female boardroom representation, according to a survey by Egon Zehnder, the recruitment firm. But executive appointments, and not non-executives drafted in, are the key to unlocking the boardroom door for the long term.

Miranda Pode, head of Egon Zehnder in the UK, said: “Whilst it’s very good news that women account for nearly 25% of board roles, the gains have almost entirely been made in non-executive positions. The bigger challenge is to carry this through into executive positions, which is a much harder task as it will require a sea change in how organisations identify and develop talented women.”

Adnams is now a progressive company, Hester says, but in the male-dominated worlds of brewing and logistics she met resistance along the way. “When I became transport manager, one of the directors, who is no longer here, said it was absolutely ridiculous that a woman should be in charge of transport.” When she became the first senior woman manager, “there were people in the room who thought I shouldn’t be there and I found that quite uncomfortable.”

Now, half of Adnams’ executive committee are women, putting them in line to follow Hester into the boardroom. One of the company’s three master brewers is a woman who persevered to get her qualification at Hester’s urging.

The push for female representation at the top of companies is not just about securing fairer representation. Studies have shown that companies with women on their boards are less susceptible to groupthink and more alive to risks.

Hester says: “If you can have a mix at a senior level, it’s less likely that anything will be missed. The biggest failure in business is when communication goes wrong somewhere.”

But she is wary of talk of “diversity” as a goal, calling instead for companies to be open minded so that talented women can make it on their own merit.

“To appoint a woman for the sake of diversity is as insulting, if not more insulting, as not appointing them because they’re a woman.”

As for women looking to make it to the top, they should stop being too hard on themselves.

“We are our own worst critics. We think if we’re at work and the kids are at home then we’re wrong and if we’re at home because our kids are ill then we’re not doing our job. You can only strive to be the best you can be.”

webTitle: Dixons Carphone rings up 2% rise as merger benefits please investors

fields.standfirst: Company upbeat about cost savings at strategy day for analysts and investors
fields.body:
The newly merged Dixons Carphone is in demand as analysts reacted positively to Wednesday's strategy day.

The company said it could reach its £80m cost savings target earlier than expected, and while not raising the amount it said it was "firmly a minimum."

In the wake of the meeting Bank of America Merrill Lynch issued a buy note and raised its target price from 400p to 420p. Investec also issued a buy note, with analyst Alistair Davies saying:

Presentations on the core UK business highlighted the resilience of both Dixons and Carphone Warehouse and management's upbeat outlook for Connected World Services (CWS) could offer long-term upside. The shares trade on a 2015 estimated PE of 15 times, with scope for upgrades as synergy numbers increase and the timeframe in which they are achieved shortens.

Analyst Nick Bubb gave some details of the meeting:

[The] strategy day in Oxford didn't do much for the Dixons Carphone share price [on Wednesday], but it was pretty confident in tone and although the company had warned, in deathless prose, that "no update on current trading will be provided during the presentation" the ebullient chief executive Seb James said quite openly that trading is going well, after a good "Back to Skool" period and strong sales of the Apple iPhone 6.
And though management decided not to increase their synergy targets at this stage, £80m is clearly the bare minimum now envisaged, thanks to early action on headquarter costs (with Hemel Hempstead to be axed next year in favour of Acton) and the marked success of the new Carphone Warehouse store-within-a-stores. And James was able to make very reassuring noises about Carphone's network relationships, having just signed an MVNO [mobile virtual network operator] agreement to get 3 back into the business. And having tied in with Apple to provide the technology to connect the handsets bought by consumers in Apple stores in the UK, management were notably more confident about the outlook for the new Connected World Services business (so much so that its results will be broken out for the first time in the interims in December).

Dixons Carphone is currently up 7.4p or 2% at 373.5p.

webTitle: FTSE boosted by Fed minutes but Vodafone hit by competition and takeover concerns

fields.standfirst: Dovish Fed comments lift markets and hit dollar, helping metal prices and mining shares
fields.body:
The US Federal Reserve has ridden to the rescue of beleaguered markets, but Vodafone is missing out.

The telecoms group is down 1.3p to 203p on worries about increased competition, and a possible pricey bid for Italian broadband firm Fastweb, said to have been put up for sale by owner Swisscom.

Nomura, highlighting competition worries, has cut its target price to 180p from 190p and downgrades Vodafone to reduce from neutral. It said:

Vodafone has outperformed the sector by 7% and the FTSE by 12% over three months and now trades at 7 times forward EBITDA (incumbents 6.5 times) compared with 5.1 times at the start of 2013. The market has priced in substantial benefits from market repair, but we believe that competition may well increase, rather than decrease over the next 12 months:
We expect new entrants in the UK, the Netherlands and India. Tougher competition is taking hold in South Africa and Turkey for the second successive quarter. Underlying growth rates are slipping. Drillisch's LTE offers will act as a check on pricing in Germany and may yet accelerate the current trend for pricing cuts in Vodafone's largest market. Yoigo will resume its discount position in Spain post consolidation of the convergent mobile virtual network operators Lastly, European corporates are exploiting data as a means to reduce voice/messaging spend. The evidence for Project Spring delivering a step-change in customer experience remains weak. Recent surveys in the UK and Germany show Vodafone in a poor light and undermine its aspiration to demonstrate and monetise a sustainable premium positioning on quality. This in turn increases our concern for Vodafone's medium-term dividend.

Espirito Santo's Andrew Hogley, meanwhile, issued a sell note at the prospect of a Fastweb bid:

Several press reports over the past couple of days (FT, Reuters) have put the possibility of a Vodafone acquisition of Fastweb back on the agenda. We do not believe that Swisscom is the right owner of this asset and can see the potential for synergies with Vodafone's Italian business but find some of the suggested multiples, in the 8 times to 10 times EBITDA range, surprising for a business that generates next to no cash flow.
We understand that Swisscom is looking to recoup its investment, which we calculate to be around €4.2bn, in our view Vodafone could not justify paying this much.

Overall though, the mood is more buoyant despite the continuing threat of the Ebola virus spreading, as well as worries about an economic slowdown, especially in China and Germany. webTitle: Payday loans shaken up by competition regulator

fields.standfirst: Competition and Markets Authority wants clearer fees and charges and for consumers to be able to compare deals online
fields.body:
Payday lenders will be forced to give details of their products on price comparison websites to help potential borrowers shop around under new competition rules for the sector.

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said payday lenders’ customers find it hard to get clear information on the cost of borrowing. Letting them compare deals online will increase competition and make it easier for new lenders to offer better prices, the CMA said.

The regulator will also require payday lenders to be clearer about their fees and charges, make it easier for borrowers to shop around without hurting their credit record, improve data sharing between lenders and oblige them to give borrowers a summary of charges.

The proposals follow a price cap announced in July by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) that limits repayments to no more than double the sum borrowed. The CMA said it wanted to make sure the cap did not stifle competition by setting a going rate for all lenders.

The FCA estimated that payday lenders issued 10m loans worth £2.5bn last year. The sector grew rapidly during the recession, but politicians and campaigners have attacked lenders for preying on vulnerable customers and charging high interest rates that risk their borrowing getting out of control.

Wonga, the biggest online payday lender, was ordered last week to write off £220m of loans to 375,000 people that it admitted should never have been granted. The advertising watchdog has also banned Wonga from using an advert that fails to mention its 5,853% annual interest rate.

Simon Polito, the chair of the CMA’s payday lending investigation group, said: “Greater price competition will make a real difference to the 1.8 million payday customers in the UK. At the moment there is little transparency on the cost of loans and partly as a result, borrowers don’t generally shop around and competition on price is weak.

“Lower prices from greater competition would be particularly welcome in this market. If you need to take out a payday loan because money is tight, you certainly don’t want to pay more than is necessary. Given that most customers take out several loans in a year, the total cost of paying too much for payday loans can build up over time.”

The CMA also recommended that lead generator websites selling potential borrowers’ details to lenders should be clearer about their activities. Many borrowers think the sites are lenders rather than middle-men and do not understand that they sell customers’ details to lenders for fees.

webTitle: National retail chains speed up high street exodus, data shows

fields.bodyText: National retail chains are quitting the high street at twice the rate of last year as pawnbrokers, building societies and women’s fashion stores close their doors. High street store closures were running at 16 a day in the first six months of this year. That was slightly down on the 18 a day recorded in the fiirst 6 months of 2013, but at the same time the rate of store openings plunged 15% – meaning the number of stores being left empty has nearly doubled. The new data is part of an analysis of the UK’s top 500 towns by the research firm Local Data Company (LDC) and accountants PwC. Just over 400 shops were left empty over the period – more than in the whole of last year. Only London and the east of England saw the number of empty shops fall with the east midlands, the north west and west midlands the hardest hit. Pawnbrokers are among the hardest hit – a sharp contrast to recent years when they have been among the high street’s winners. Their numbers reduced by 7%, the third highest faller behind video rental stores and building societies. A slump in the gold price and a rise in alternative ways to raise cash through payday lenders such as Wonga have caused an about-turn in the fortunes of pawnbrokers, underlined by the collapse and rescue of Albermarle Bond. About a third of the chain’s stores were closed when it went into administration. Rival chains, including H&T, have also closed outlets. Mark Hudson, retail leader at PwC, said: “this data shows that we are now really starting to see the full effects of the digital revolution and consequent change in customer behaviour play out on the high street.” A survey by Experian earlier this week, which focused on high street changes over the past decade, showed that the number of convenience stores and tattoo parlours had nearly tripled, while travel agents and womenswear shops were in steep decline and video rental outlets have almost entirely disappeared. Matthew Hopkinson, director of LDC, said that many big retailers were reducing their overall number of outlets to reflect a change in shopping habits towards online shopping and large retail parks. He said: “They now want small stores as a local touchpoint or large stores where they can create an experiential environment and really engage with customers. Where once they would have had three stores including one on the high street now they just want one.” But Hopkinson said the overall picture for the high street was more rosy than the PwC figures suggested because spare space was being taken up by independent retailers. Figures to be released on Monday will reveal a rise in the number of independent shops so that the overall number of stores left empty on Britain’s high streets remains steady.

webTitle: 60% of Britain’s top firms still to reach government target for female directors

fields.standfirst: 61 FTSE 100 companies still haven’t met Lord Davies’ target of 25% female representation on boards, government data shows
fields.body:
Six out of 10 of Britain’s largest companies are failing to hit a government target for hiring female directors, new government data revealed on Thursday.

The figure has emerged within the latest report on how UK businesses are progressing towards a Department for Business Innovation and Skills (BIS) target for 25% of FTSE 100 directors to be female by next year.

The goal, set during Lord Davies’ review of women on boards in 2011, stated: “FTSE 100 boards should aim for a minimum of 25% female representation by 2015 and we expect that many will achieve a higher figure”.

However, with less than three months of 2014 remaining, 61 of the FTSE 100 have still to reach 25%, including some of the index’s largest firms. They include: Reckitt Benckiser, the household products group behind brands such as Dettol and Vanish; the oil giant BP; and the commodity trading firm Glencore.

The news came as BIS said that 22.8% of directors of FTSE 100 companies are now female, up from 20.7% in March. The statistics represent increases from 12.5% when Davies launched his report in 2011 and 17.3% in April 2013. However, the overall figure is boosted by women in part-time roles, with 27.9% of FTSE 100 non-executive directors being women, compared with the 8.4% in executive directorships.

The business Secretary Vince Cable said: “Although our target is in sight, we must keep up the momentum. All companies with fewer than 25% of women on their board need to take firm action now to increase female representation.”

Apart from the sluggish progress in the FTSE 100, the picture is bleaker within the second division FTSE 250. There, women’s representation in boardrooms has increased to 17.4% – up from 15.6% in March 2014, with the figures depressed by 29 FTSE 250 firms having no female directors at all. The companies that retain all male boards include: retailer JD Sports; the pub group Enterprise Inns; and the insurer Brit.

Lord Davies added: “Having reached a position where it is unacceptable for the voice of women to be absent from the boardroom, it is disappointing to see there are still 29 all-male boards in the FTSE 250. Every single company needs to address the issue of gender balance in the boardroom and make sure they support UK business in our collective goal.”

While the numbers of women in top UK boardrooms have been increasing slowly, there are many men and women in the City who categorise the Davies report as a success as it has kick-started progress towards greater equality in the workplace.

The new figures have been published just days after Cable said he was preparing to launch a review into the lack of ethnic minority directors in Britain’s boardrooms, in a move that closely mirrors the work undertaken by Lord Davies on female directors. It also follows Royal Bank of Scotland saying it is considering introducing targets for the number of senior female employees in an attempt to address the gender imbalance at the group. Alison Rose, head of commercial and private banking at RBS, said she supported the idea of “aspirational targets” for the bank.

The government’s figures were also published alongside similar research showing that UK companies are among the world’s most frequent employers of female directors.

The report, from headhunters Egon Zehnder, placed the UK joint fourth in a global league table showing countries with the highest proportion of female directors, from a sample of 1,000 companies in more than 40 countries. Norway topped the list with 38%, followed by France with 28.5%, Sweden 27.5% and the UK and Australia on 22.6%.

webTitle: Britain’s economic recovery ‘to stall’ without campaign to boost exports

fields.bodyText: Britain’s economic recovery will stall unless there is a national campaign to improve the UK’s export performance, a leading business lobby group has warned. The British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) said a slowdown in UK manufacturing and exports was a warning bell for the economy and must be answered with radical action from businesses and the government. Economists are widely predicting that economic growth slowed between July and September, following 0.9% growth in the second quarter. The first official estimate will be published on 24 October by the Office for National Statistics. The British Chambers of Commerce said the strong growth in manufacturing at the start of the year had run its course, with more factories running below full capacity and exporters concerned about a stronger pound which makes UK goods more expensive abroad. John Longworth, director general of the BCC, said: “We may be hearing the first alarm bell for the UK economy, but this need not be the case. “The disappointing decline in exports highlights that we must do something radically different. Britain faces a major challenge in improving its trade performance, so we must waste no time in supporting trade opportunities to overseas markets which offer sustained growth. Only a concerted national campaign and sustained investment will allow more UK firms to look beyond our shores for growth opportunities.” The BCC’s survey of more than 7,000 businesses across the UK found that manufacturers experienced a sharp slowdown in sales growth at home and abroad in the third quarter. A balance of +16% of manufacturers reported a rise in export sales, down from +30% in the second quarter. It was the lowest balance since the fourth quarter of 2012. Growth in domestic manufacturing orders was also sharply lower than the second quarter. Companies in the services sector reported a better third quarter, with domestic sales and orders roughly growing at the same rate as the second quarter. However, services companies also reported that export sales grew at the slowest pace since the fourth quarter of 2012. The survey is a reminder of the scale of the challenge facing the government in its bid to rebalance the economy away from consumer spending and financial services and towards manufacturing and exports. The BCC warned in August George Osborne will miss his target of doubling UK exports to £1tn by 2020 because the government had failed to “put its money where its mouth is”. It said exports would have to grow by 10% a year to meet the target set by the chancellor in 2012, which appears out of reach given the lack of progress. The BCC has called on the government to freeze business rates for all companies until 2017 when a planned revaluation of premises will take place. It also wants the whole business rates system – which the BCC says is a barrier to business investment – to be reviewed and reformed by 2022. Commenting on the BCC’s latest survey, its chief economist David Kern, said: “Noticeable falls in all the export balances and increased signs of slower growth require a forceful policy response. UK growth cannot rely permanently on consumer spending, and on unsustainable current account and budget deficits. Unless exports and investment play a bigger role in growth, the recovery will stall.” The group’s report echoed recent evidence from the Office for National Statistics and other business surveys that manufacturing and the wider economy lost steam in the third quarter. The BCC said concerns over the pound, as well as a worsening outlook for the eurozone, reinforced the case against an early rise in interest rates which the lobby group said would endanger the recovery.

webTitle: Beyond the headlines about economic growth it's not all gloom and doom

fields.standfirst: IMF cutting projections for 2015 world GDP growth from 4.0% to 3.85% is more of a reversion to previous expectations
fields.body:
Yesterday the IMF cut its forecast for world economic growth for both 2014 and 2015, causing stocks to drop 1.5% in New York and 1% in Australia. However, the general gloom that spread from the report obscured the fact that for Australia the news was not all bad.

The lack of optimism in the title of the IMF’s world economic report, “Legacies, Clouds, Uncertainties” is reflected throughout much of the language used by the IMF in its outlook for the world’s economy, and continues nearly four years of depressing reading in the six monthly IMF reports.

The opening remarks of the report are so glum you’d think they’re from a Smiths song. The IMF’s economic counsellor, Oliver Blanchard, explains in the report’s foreword that the world economy “is in the middle of a balancing act”. Normally you might think that would mean balancing good signs with some dangers or risks. But no, Blanchard just sees the balancing involving bad now with bad to come.

Blanchard suggests that on the one hand “countries must address the legacies of the global financial crisis, ranging from debt overhangs to high unemployment. On the other, they face a cloudy future.”

And just to reinforce the feeling that Blanchard spent the night before writing his foreword staying up listening to Meat is Murder, he concludes this opening paragraph by noting “potential growth rates are being revised downward, and these worsened prospects are in turn affecting confidence, demand, and growth today”.

Geez, Blanchard, heaven knows I’m miserable now.

But never fear. Things actually aren’t that bad.

The gloom really comes from the IMF cutting the projections for world GDP growth for 2015 from the 4.0% it predicted in July to 3.85%. But this isn’t that bad given that back in April the IMF was expecting the world economy to grow by 3.88% – so it is really more of a reversion to previous expectations than a sudden downturn.

Since the GFC, the IMF has continually been overly optimistic in its projections. In September 2011 it thought the world economy in 2015 would grow by 4.8%, a year later they were expecting it to grow by 4.4%. In October 2013 they had revised down the expected growth to 4.0%, and now it is 3.8%:

The reason for the most recent declines in projections for the world’s growth is a bit complicated, because the economic picture is rather disjointed. The US and Britain “are leaving the crisis behind and achieving decent growth” but even here, the joy is tempered by knowledge that “potential growth is now lower than in the early 2000s”.

The IMF is letting us know that the best we can do is not as much as before. Part of this is because of other downgrades. The euro area continues to be a sad sack of an economic area, with the IMF noting that growth “nearly stalled” there earlier this year. But the big concern is the developing nations – notably China.

Back in 2011, the IMF thought China would grow by 9.5% in 2015; now it expects just 7.1% growth for next year:

But Australia’s growth in 2015 is actually expected to be better than the IMF thought it would be this time last year, and both the Britain and the US are in better shape than the IMF expected they would be 12 months ago.

However, Australia is also affected by an overall decline in potential growth. While the IMF is not forecasting dire times ahead for us, they are rather dreary compared to what we have been used to over the past 20 years. From 1994 to 2007, a minimum of 3% annual GDP growth was almost taken as given, and the average of 3.7% during that period reflects that it would often be much higher.

But from now till 2019, the IMF sees 3% growth being as good as it gets:

Perhaps surprisingly, this isn’t that bad compared to other advanced economies. Australia’s projected growth rate from now till 2019 makes it to the top half of the IMF’s major advanced economies:

Our GDP per capita growth, however, is less impressive – Australia is growing slower than the US, UK and New Zealand.

Amid the media reports of the figures was the claim that Australia’s unemployment rate was set to be second worst in Asia-Pacific. This is sort of true if you exclude Fiji and Mongolia, but it also isn’t that much of a concern. Australia’s unemployment rate is generally higher than these other nations. They may be our geographic neighbours, but given the difference in size, economic conditions, regulations, wages and infrastructure they’re not really our economic peers. Yes, since last year Indonesia and New Zealand look to have a better unemployment rate than us, but other than that there has been little change.

And given that our GDP per capita is roughly 25% larger than the next best in the region, we shouldn’t be too hard on ourselves:

Moreover, New Zealand having a lower rate is just a return to the norm. In only 10 years since 1980 has New Zealand’s unemployment rate been higher than Australia’s – and half of those occurred during and after the GFC.

Across the major advanced economies, our ranking in unemployment is expected to remain pretty much where it has usually been. In 2014, out of 26 major advanced economies, we’re ranked 12th and by 2017 we’re expected to be 14th:

But, as ever, we must remember these are just projections and subject to the same weaknesses as any economic measure. The ABS is currently having problems calculating what the unemployment rate was last month, and the IMF has had to significantly change some of its projections in the space of just three months.

So yes, there’s gloom in these figures, but we are not bound by them. There is enough bad economic news around without us having to start suggesting we’re performing worse than nations in the area that would kill for our standard of living.

As I noted on Tuesday, the IMF sees opportunities in this environment for improved growth through infrastructure building. It would be nice to see some of this growth occur. Because after five years of the IMF continually predicting weak growth only to further revise them down six months later, the joke isn’t funny anymore.
